metadata.sermon_start_end: Any Presbyterians here this evening? When I was young I was told that Presbyterians were bad because they believed in predestination. Nobody had any freedom, everything was figured out for you ahead of time and there wasn’t anything you could do about it. But you can’t fool all of [...] help us so to know thee that we may truly love thee, so to love thee that we may fully serve thee, whom to serve is perfect freedom. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Romans 7 as a springboard for a thematic discussion on free will versus predestination. However, it fails Dekker's primary test: finding what is in THIS text that is nowhere else. Instead of a meticulous recreation of Paul's specific logic, the text is used to validate a pre-existing interest in Tolkien and Lewis. It treats the Bible passage as a 'biblical idea' rather than a unique proclamatory word.
quotes: But let’s listen again to what St. Paul says about this.
This is pure Christian doctrine right out of Romans 7 and 8.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific linguistic tension in Romans 7 (the 'I' vs 'Sin') rather than immediately jumping to external literary illustrations to explain the concept.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no attention to the original context, the Greek text, or the historical situation of the Roman congregation. The preacher relies on Augustine, Luther, and Barth as intermediaries rather than performing primary exegesis. The requirement for knowledge of Hebrew/Greek and biblical history is not visible in the text.
quotes: After Paul, the person who best described this situation was St. Augustine of Hippo...
Martin Luther, following Augustine and Paul, wrote about the bondage of the will.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific historical-theological context of Paul’s argument regarding the Law (Torah) and the 'I', rather than treating it as a general psychological or systematic-theological treatise.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its cultural references (mustard choices, Bob Dole, Tolkien movies). It successfully identifies the 'zeitgeist' of the American gospel of Free Will. However, it leans heavily on pop culture (Tolkien) as the primary mode of application rather than the biblical text applying itself to the hearer's life.
quotes: I go to the store to buy mustard and I am confronted by fifty different kinds of mustard.
When Bob Dole was running for president, his speech coach taped reminders to his refrigerator...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond literary analogies (Frodo/Gollum) to more direct, spiritual applications of how the 'Law of the Spirit' specifically breaks contemporary bondages.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is interwoven, but not in the way Dekker envisions. It interweaves literature (Tolkien/Lewis) with application, while the biblical exposition remains thin. The hearer is drawn into Middle-earth more than they are drawn into the biblical text.
quotes: Now we have arrived at Frodo and The Lord of the Rings.
This is a parallel to Adam and Eve, who took the forbidden fruit.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'exposition' of the Greek/Hebrew text is what is being applied, rather than using the text as a proof-coat for literary analysis.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon follows the movement from misery (bondage of the will) to redemption (Christ setting us free) to gratitude (doing good works). It correctly identifies misery as 'misery before God' and redemption as external grace.
quotes: Paul is describing a war that goes on in the human being all the time.
The law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set me free...
You can go forward with confidence to do those good works that God has prepared for you...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' section by connecting it more to the specific 'Law' mentioned in Romans 7 rather than just psychological procrastination.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'two ways' seriously, particularly the possibility of being 'lost in time' (Gollum as a figure of total corruption). It rejects the 'liberal' notion that man cannot be lost, emphasizing the gravity of the will's direction.
quotes: Gollum has become a slimy, hideous, disgusting creature who skulks about in the dark.
Sin and Death decide things for us. We have no will left in the matter.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'eternal loss' aspect mentioned in Dekker’s thesis to the 'Law of Sin and Death' to sharpen the stakes.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is present as the 'telos' and the source of freedom. However, the sermon spends significantly more time on the mechanics of the will and Tolkien's narrative than on the person and work of Christ Himself. Christ appears as a functional solution to a philosophical problem.
quotes: This is the heart of the new story that is written in the Cross of Christ.
The law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set me free from the law of sin and death.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Develop the 'two natures' or the specific work of Christ more substantively so He is not just a 'point of power' but the incarnate Lord.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2,150 words, the sermon meets the requirement for breadth. It allows for the 'depth' of the argument to develop over 20+ minutes.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the available time to increase exegetical depth rather than expanding literary illustrations.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily in its lack of specific biblical exposition. It functions more as a theological essay on 'Theology in Tolkien' than an 'exposition of a specific Bible passage.' While it captures the 'three parts' and the 'two ways' effectively, it treats the Bible as a source of general truths or 'ideas' rather than a unique, current word that must be recreated from the original languages and context.
strengths: Strong adherence to the three-fold structure of misery, redemption, and gratitude.
Effective identification of the zeitgeist regarding 'free will' and consumer choice.
Maintains the seriousness of being 'lost' through the character of Gollum.
weaknesses: Severe lack of primary exegesis; no engagement with the original Greek or the specific context of the Roman church.
Over-reliance on literary figures (Frodo, Ransom) to carry the weight of the proclamation.
The biblical text is used as a 'keyword' or 'idea' rather than the central, unique authority.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s criteria, this is a borderline sermon. While it is a 'strong speech' about the Gospel and the human condition, its failure to center on the 'exposition' of the specific pericope (Thesis 1.3 and 2) makes it more of a theological lecture than a sermon in the strict sense.
